Key Match Events: Francisco Lindor, competing with the Dodgers Shohei Ohtani in the NL MVP race, reached base three times, scored a run and drove in another.
Brandon Nimmo couldn’t come up with a diving catch in center of Ceddanne Rafaela’s liner, which went for a one-out triple.
Tyler O’Neill fumbled the ball down the line, allowing Luis Torrens to score.
Pre-Game Insights: Every series had become “a must-win series” for the rest of the year, as the Mets look to go from 11 games under.500 on June 2 to the postseason.

Severino said every time Boston comes to New York, it’s a big game. … We’re really close to being in a playoff spot, so from now on, every time they give me the ball, it’s a chance for me to get my team closer to the playoffs.
Post-Match Reflections: What a story,” Carlos Mendoza said. “There’s been a lot of ups and downs, but we never quit. Here we are playing meaningful games in September, but we haven’t done anything. We know where we are.
This was a fun night, being back here in our house in front of a really good crowd,’’ Mendoza said.
Miscellaneous Highlights: The Mets won their fifth straight game to get within a half game of the idle Braves for the final NL wild-card spot.
The Mets reached a season-high 10 games over.500 (74-64) with Monday’s win, their sixth in their last seven games.
The victory came in front of a home crowd of 35,149, their highest attendance without a fan giveaway since they hosted the Yankees in the Subway Series on June 26.
